facts: Examines "write to learn" research, noting that 18% of studies showed negative effects when students were overwhelmed. Argues that explicit instruction (like TWR methods) modulates cognitive load.

author: Tim Surma, Paul A. Kirschner, et al.
topic: Five Common Misconceptions About the Knowledge-Rich Curriculum
facts: Addresses misconceptions about knowledge-rich curricula, including fears that education will be reduced to mindless drills. Based on development of new knowledge-rich minimum goals for Flemish primary education.

author: Paul Kirschner (3-Star Learning)
facts: Research showing stimulus-rich decorated classrooms lead to more off-task behavior (38.6% vs 28.4%) and lower learning outcomes. Directly applies cognitive load theory to classroom environment design.

author: Paul Kirschner (3-Star Learning)
topic: What is Good for Performance Often is Not Good for Learning
facts: Explores the distinction between performance (immediate demonstration) and learning (durable, transferable knowledge)—core concept in cognitive load theory and desirable difficulties research.

author: Paul Kirschner (kirschner-ED)
topic: Rethinking Cognitive Load Theory for Collaborative Learning
facts: Explains Collaborative Cognitive Load Theory (CCLT), distinguishing biologically primary skills from biologically secondary knowledge (like writing) requiring explicit instruction. Discusses transaction costs of group work.

author: Van Merriënboer, Kirschner, P. A., & Frèrejean, J.
topic: Ten Steps to Complex Learning (2024 Edition)
facts: Updated edition of comprehensive instructional design model for complex cognitive skills—applicable to designing writing instruction sequences.

author: Carl Hendrick
facts: 15,000+ subscribers, ranked #45 in Education. Features research analysis and essays on education fashions, blind spots and counterintuitive truths about learning.

author: Carl Hendrick
topic: Cognitive Load Theory: Emerging Trends and Innovations
facts: Comprehensive review of new CLT special issue with 15+ empirical papers covering split-attention strategies, interleaving, worked examples, emotion role in cognitive load. Directly applicable to structuring writing instruction.

author: Carl Hendrick
facts: Critiques ed-tech failure to incorporate instructional invariants—fundamental conditions under which learning occurs. Relevant to evidence-based writing instruction principles.

author: Carl Hendrick
facts: Announces new book "Instructional Illusions" co-authored with Paul Kirschner (available August 2025). Discusses the engagement illusion—how visible engagement often correlates with less effective learning.

author: Carl Hendrick
topic: AI in Schools: Three Things to Get Right
facts: Evidence-based framework for AI implementation in schools, maintaining teacher judgment at center—relevant to AI writing tools in classrooms.

author: Carl Hendrick
facts: Keynote presentation at ResearchED Greenwich conference on evidence-based education practices.
